segments.text: This is an interview with Roberto Garcia by Leticia Garcia on April 23rd in Palestine, Texas concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I am going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
Yes, that's all right with me.
I'd like to start off by getting a brief background of your military career, such as why and when you joined, to give us an understanding of your experiences before Vietnam.
To better understand where I came from, you might say I was raised in a large family in a farming community.
My father was a small farmer, my mother a housewife.
I have a high school education.
I graduated in May of 1955.
After graduating, I worked for
four years, after four years of working in a company where I was a stock boy, I decided that life was a little unexciting.
I thought that I wanted to do better things.
I decided that the military was about the best way that I could do it.
So in December of 1958, I joined the military service.
I
took basic training, advanced individual training, and was, subsequent to that, assigned to a signal company in Fairbanks, Alaska for two years.
After completing my overseas tour in Alaska, I came back.
I served approximately a year in Fort Benning, Georgia, again as a communicator.
I was separated from the service in
March of 1962.
I stayed out for approximately three months after having been a civilian again for approximately three months.
I decided that life in the military was not all that bad and I rejoined the military.
Can you tell me when you were sent to Vietnam why you went and your initial reactions to going?
I went to Vietnam.
I had rejoined the military service.
I was stationed with a tactical communications company in Fort Riley, Kansas.
I had been in the Army, back in the Army, approximately four months.
One day I was called to the company and I was informed that I had orders for Germany.
I was happy about the assignment because I had not
been to Germany.
And I lived with that for approximately one week.
In about a week they called me back into the company and told me that my orders for Germany had been cancelled and that I was being sent to Vietnam.
Vietnam at that time was a very small insurgency guerrilla warfare type of a thing going on.
I was elated.
I looked upon it as an adventure, something that very few people were doing at that time, going to Vietnam, and I was really looking forward to it.
Did your initial thoughts change after you had been there, say, like a couple months or so?
Well, yes, in a way.
I went to Vietnam, and it didn't take me long to find out that it was not really an exciting thing.
It was new, everything that we did from day to day, or the experiences that we went through, I guess you might say, were still new.
However, after, say, three or four months, we more or less, or I more or less, settled upon a routine.
And I found it somewhat boring.
The thoughts that I had about Vietnam was that it was going to be an exciting place, something
Exciting happened every day and I found much too much.
Much to my dismay that this would not be a case.
Can you tell me like the conditions of the country at the time that you want?
What were they like?
Well, the conditions over there.
Even though they were somewhat different than what I would have expected to find.
Were
that it is a very poor country, that people live very poorly.
Their facilities are not anywhere near what they are here in the United States.
Transportation at that time, and I imagine that it's still the same, was almost nonexistent.
As far as modern transportation, the people still depended upon bicycles as their main means of transportation.
The people live in very poor houses.
Their income is almost nothing in comparison to ours.
They do not have the furniture
or the appliances that we accept as an everyday common thing here in the United States.
What was your unit's mission in support of the war, and how did you fit in as far as your duties went?
The unit that I was assigned to was the 232nd Signal Company, parentheses, Combat Support, close the parentheses.

We were responsible for establishing communications, and by communications I mean teletype and communication center and telephone communications from major headquarters to major headquarters and down to a certain extent to subordinate level.
Initially, I served on a communication site
for approximately two months as a non-commissioned officer in charge of a shift between 11 o'clock at night and 7 o'clock in the morning.
After approximately three months, I was presented with the opportunity to serve as a unit operations sergeant.
I accepted that job flatly.
It was a very challenging job.
We were responsible for administering or supervising the overall mission type functions of the unit.
We had approximately 11 sites that we provided the support to maintain the communications and also the planning
I'm sure you didn't work 24 hours a day all the time.
Can you tell me a little bit about what the American soldiers did for relaxation?
Yes, just like any other place, depending upon the individual, we all did different things, even though most of us had some other things in common more than others.
The average soldier would, once he got off of work,
Relax for a small while.
Then there were several activities sponsored by the military.
We had the equipment to become engaged in sports activities, if you so desired.
There were libraries that the soldier could go to and pick up a book and maybe relax for a few minutes or a few hours.
They were not elaborate libraries.
They were somewhat limited in the number of books available.
However, the libraries were there.
There were the movies which, even though somewhat limited, were available.
The unit would
petty circuit wherein certain movies were shown throughout the Republic of Vietnam.
During the course of a week, they would be rotated from one place to another, and some people engaged in watching movies.
We, I think the majority of us, became involved in two things.
One was playing cards.
We would begin playing cards.

Sometime during the course of the evening, normally not too long after supper, we would play either poker, either for money or just for what we termed penny ante, or we would just play for the fun of it.
And of course, just like the reputation that had been given to the military, a lot of us
got involved in drinking and sitting and talking for hours upon hours as a means to pass the time away.
There was also a lot of time spent in writing letters.
At that time, we didn't have the cassettes that are available nowadays, so the average soldier would correspond with his family's friends back in the States, also for long periods of time.
There were other things.
One of the things that I did on the average once a week, maybe twice a week, we would go into downtown Saigon, which was only approximately 10 miles from where I was stationed.
That is my experience with the average things a person would do for his off-duty activities.
Was there a big involvement with drugs and alcohol?
Initially, on my first tour, you've got to understand that this was back in the early 1960s, 1962, matter of fact.
Drugs were almost nonexistent.
When you talk about drugs, you were talking about a person that was not ordinary.
He was out of the ordinary.
if a person were using drugs who was not accepted as being a person that you wanted to get involved with.
So no drugs in the sense that we use drugs in were nonexistent at the time.
The alcohol was there, yes, the alcohol was there.
Okay.
Can you tell me why the U.S. became involved in the war?
Or why you feel they became involved in the war?
Our involvement in the war stems from an agreement, the Southeastern Asia Treaty Organization, in which we were a partner.
That agreement came into existence, best of my knowledge, just like the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, NATO.
Immediately after World War II,

people, the parties, the politicians in existence at that time must have determined that it would be wise to come up with such organizations and to come up with such agreements and basically what they stated was that if I get attacked I'm going to ask for your assistance or if I
get a threat to my party's power.
Somebody is trying to usurp that existing government.
I, if necessary, I'm going to ask for assistance and all nations that are co-signers of that treaty are
more or less required to come to my assistance.
We were a co-signee of that treaty, so were the Australians, so were the Philippines, so were the Vietnamese.
We had different nations involved in that treaty.
The president of Vietnam at that time was
new non-Nadim, if I remember correctly, he evidently found it advisable to ask for our assistance.
Initially, we started by only sending military advisors.
Matter of fact, I went as a military advisor the first time that we went over, which meant that we were there as a guest of that nation,

that we were not involved in any war activities other than advising the vietnamese when i went over the first time like i say in 1962 the advisory group was a very very small force we were down to about approximately uh 10 15 000 american soldiers this is army navy and air force combined
So at the time in 1962, America's involvement in the war wasn't an active one?

It was not an active one, even though some advisors, and I'm talking about the infantry type, the ranger type, they would go along with regular Vietnamese armies whenever they went out on search and destroy missions.

Inadvertently, it was necessary that they fire in their defense, and I'd like to reiterate that at that time, an American soldier, even though he carried a weapon with ammunition, was instructed that he would only use that weapon as a means of self-defense.
In answer to your question, yes, it was a very small part that we played at that time.
How did the Vietnamese react to the war, such as the feelings towards Americans and their overall attitude?
My experience or my interaction with Vietnamese on my first tour was very limited, and I can only speak from those limited encounters that I had with the Vietnamese.

But the impression that I got was that initially the Vietnamese accepted us as somewhat super beings, that their propaganda machine had told them that we were extremely powerful, extremely kind, and extremely benevolent, that we were the, quote, good guys.

I also got the impression that as time went along, the Vietnamese found out that we, to quote them, were same thing, that we were also human, that we were not necessarily the nice guy that we had been talked about to be.
So to begin with, in 1962, they were pretty much supportive of Americans?
Those that I talked to were very supportive of Americans.
But like I said, as time went along, I got the impression that they were disenchanted with our actions.
What about back home in the United States in 1962?
Were the Americans supportive of the war?
In 1962, yes, the Americans were supportive of the war.
They, at that time, the military, that stigma to the military was popular to serve in the defense of the nation.
The soldiers were still proud to wear the uniform.
They were looked upon with respect.
people would go out of their way to try to be helpful to them.
And generally, yes, the general public had a favorable support for the Vietnam War.
As the war progressed through the 60s, did you note any changes of what we just discussed, say like America's involvement in the war?
Yes, there was a definite change in the general public's attitude of our involvement in the war.
I do not think that the soldiers' way of thinking about the war changed.
There was, in the United States at that time, a movement mainly
at the college level to question and attack our involvement of the war.
As this movement increased, and I might say that it was not only at the college level, there were certain groups, not necessarily communistic,
were 100 percent opposed to our involvement in the war, and they very actively politicked and questioned our involvement in the war.
As the movement became stronger, as the feelings became stronger, as the demonstrations became stronger, politicians for whatever
their reasons either selfish or if they in actuality thought that our involvement was wrong, continuously attacked our policies.
They questioned the President's authority.
They questioned the amount of money that was being spent in the effort.
They questioned the number of lives that were being lost in the war.
They questioned the military's decisions.
They questioned their authority to bomb another country.
They questioned the authority to pursue the enemy beyond certain lines.
All in all, I would venture to say from the middle 60s, 1965,
through the latter part of the 60s and particularly in the 70s until the end of the war, the attitude of the nation did a 100% turnabout.
You mentioned a while ago that you served as an advisor the first time you went.
Was that the same status you served as the second time around?
No.
Like I mentioned, when I went over on my first tour, we were a very small force at the time.
We were not authorized to conduct aggressive activities.
We could only fire a weapon as a matter of self-defense.
If you will remember, or if you have read any history books, though,
Sometime in 1964, August 1964, if I remember correctly, the United States stated, even though it was questioned by various ways, that United States ships had been attacked by North Vietnamese
patrol boats in the Gulf of Tonkin.
We refer to it as the Gulf of Tonkin incident.
Whatever the case may have been, the United States used that incident to further expand its war effort, whereas we had been maintaining a small number
of military personnel in Vietnam.
Even though it had progressed, in 1964 we had somewhere about 100,000 military personnel in Vietnam.
After the Gulf of Tonkin incident, not too long after that, within a year, the United States had increased its
total military force to approximately 300,000, 350,000.
By virtue of that, and mind you, I am not familiar with international law, under what circumstances you will change from an advisor status to an active war maker, you might say.
But during that course, anyhow, the United States dropped its advisory status in Vietnam and became actively involved, as you might want to term it, an aggressor force in Vietnam.
Can you tell me about your second tour in Vietnam?
Was it voluntary?
Yes.
At that time, I was serving in Fort Hood, Texas.
The unit that I was in was alerted that they would be going to Vietnam.
We went through approximately 11 months of intensive preparation and training.
Because of the regulations at that time, I was exempt
from going to Vietnam unless I signed a waiver waiving my rights to that exemption because I had been back in Vietnam for less than 24 months.
However, at the time, I had been back in the United States 22 months and I thought that if I did not go with that unit,

that i would eventually as soon as my 24 months were up would be going to vietnam anyhow i considered my option uh the pros and the cons i had people that were very professional in that company uh i was friends with them i knew how they operated
I had trust and faith in them.
I was serving in a position of authority.
The promotions at that time, if you were serving in the position, particularly in Vietnam, you could almost be assured of a promotion.
So I took all these things into consideration, figured

These things that I have just talked about on the positive side, on the contrary side, I figured that if I did not go with a unit with people that I already knew and respected, that I would eventually be going separately, possibly with another unit, people that I was not familiar with.
So consequently, yes, I signed a waiver and I did go to Vietnam.
So is this the same unit you went with the first time?
No, this was the 54th Signal Battalion.
We also provided communications at core level down to division level.
And though this might seem strange to you, the concept is there.
It's a good concept.
We're in the concept dictates
the type of support that you are required to provide to the different echelons of command within the Corps.
And within the Corps, you take and figure that you are serving or supporting, and the figure may vary, but anywhere between, say, 75 to 150,000 soldiers.
What about the other soldiers that you went with?
Did they want to go voluntarily or were they dragged out there?
No.
My experience was that the majority of the soldiers, I only knew of two through my entire Vietnam experience, that hesitated to go to Vietnam.
The average soldier wanted to go to Vietnam.
I knew quite a few even those that were married and had families that volunteered to go to Vietnam.
This may seem somewhat strange but it's true and the only thing that I can attribute that to is that in the military we all like to be considered as professionals and our job whether
you want to put that tag on it or not, is to go out there and kill.
We figured that if we did not serve in Vietnam, or those were my thoughts anyhow, we were not doing our job.
Matter of fact, those that did, like I said, I knew two people that declined to go to Vietnam or did not want to go to Vietnam.
they were looked upon as being somewhat odd.
But in answer to your question, yes, the average soldier did want to go to Vietnam, some for patriotic reasons, even though those were very few exceptions.
I think the majority of us did it for the professionalism.
You had mentioned earlier that back in 1962, there wasn't that big of a problem with drugs.
How about in 1965?
I think the drugs in 1965 were just beginning to surface.
Generally, not only in the military but also in society, drugs were not a problem in the early 1960s.
They were there.
The heroin was there.
The morphine was there.
There were none of these...

Elaborate drugs that are available now the cocaine was almost non-existent generally At that time it was the marijuana and in the Far East of the opium In the early 1960s we were going still going through the 1940 late 1940 1950 era whereas cigarette smoking and
beer drinking, alcohol drinking was the thing to do.
So if you're asking was there a drug problem in the sense where the beer drinking, the alcohol consumption was there, yes, we had that problem, if you want to call it a problem.
But in as far as taking the hard drugs, no, it was almost nonexistent.
I, on my second tour, I served as communication chief for a site and I had ranging anywhere between 29 and 45 was the most, I had 45 soldiers.
I became quite
Familiar with their actions, I lived with them 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, and I knew them pretty thoroughly.
And I think I can honestly say that there was never any drugs in the number of people that I managed and supervised.
Beer drinking, yes, we had it just about every day, but as far as drugs, no, we didn't have it.
I left Vietnam, and to the best of my knowledge, drugs became a problem.
Hard drugs became a problem in the 1968 and 69 era.
How had the relations between the Vietnamese Americans changed between 62 and 65?
In the early 60s, in 1962,
Like I say, we were still held somewhat in awe, even though that attitude may have been changing.
In 1965, when I was there again, I think there was a total lack of respect, mutual respect.
lack of respect between the Vietnamese and the Americans.
The Vietnamese were taking the Americans as a means of making money.
The Americans had adopted the attitude that the Vietnamese were lazy and didn't know how to fight a war.
Consequently, the strategy changed at that time

wherein the American soldier was now doing all the war-making, going out and actually fighting the war, and the Vietnamese were more or less held back in reserve and were providing support-type duties.
There was a 100% turnabout.
There was a lack of respect.
they didn't like us and for the most part I think I can say that the Americans did not like the Vietnamese.
What was the Vietnamese public's feelings about the war?
The general public
And by the general public, I'm talking about maybe 80, 90% of the population.
And again, I'm talking about people that were living out in the country.
They were farmers.
They were poor people.
They were uneducated.
The only thing that these people knew anything about was what they heard on the radio, and radio was prevalent throughout Vietnam.
The general public
did not really care, I'm talking about the Vietnamese general public, did not really care about the controversy or the issues of the war.
They were concerned about raising their crops, raising the family, doing the things that a family does.
They were not too politically oriented.
As far as the impression that I got,

was that the general vietnamese didn't want a part of the war they wanted to be left alone however as the war escalated and as they lost our respect for us and as the enemy stepped up its propaganda and by the enemy i'm talking about the uh the north vietnamese in particular

and also the Vietcong, as they stepped up their propaganda, then a lot of these people that did not want a part of the war listened to the propaganda being broadcast or published or distributed by the North Vietnamese.
They became to accept us as the enemy.
We were no longer there in the defense of their nation, though we were there in the defense of a government that was by then in disfavor with the general public.
Was the Vietnamese's attitudes about fighting the war different from that of the Americans?
The Vietnamese's

you say their their feelings the soldier i guess in any country is going to feel that he is doing the right thing because he is a professional uh what their private thoughts may have been i cannot answer that however as a professional soldier they were
more or less bound to do whatever their superiors command that they do.
What about their tactics?
Were they different in fighting this war?
The Texas were definitely different.
The United States, I think, went over with a concept of fighting a war like
back in World War I and World War II, and maybe even Korea, where they were definite established battle lines.
The military refers to them as the forward edge of the battle area.
In Vietnam, there was not any such thing.
The enemy could not be identified because he was not in uniform.
The enemy did not have established battle lines
They would surface during the night or even during the day unexpectedly.
They would conduct a raid.
They would retreat.
They would become members of the general public during the day.
That was one of the major reasons, I guess you might say, why we were not successful in Vietnam.
We did not know who the enemy was.
There were times when the enemy was found and attacked, or there were times when the enemy would attack.
Battles would last for anywhere between a week at the very most to 15 days.
The enemy would then dissolve, it seemed like, into almost nothing, or he would retreat to what at that time were considered sanctuaries.
We refer to this as guerrilla warfare, where you strike and you retreat, where you make a stand for a few days and then disappear.
We were not prepared for this type of insurgency type of warfare.
We were prepared and we had the firepower to fight a conventional war.
Guerrilla warfare is definitely not a conventional type of fighting, and we were not prepared for it.
How was the military back in the States after seeing that the Vietnamese were fighting a guerrilla war?
How did they change their...
Their concept of fighting did not change.
The United States wanted to continue with a conventional type of warfare.
There were, of course, other means for trying to locate.
For instance, we had
numbers and numbers of helicopter units over there that would carry the soldier to the battlefield.
However, as happened quite often, the enemy was just not there.
How could you tell the difference between which Vietnamese were fighting with you or against you?
That was what I tried to expand upon a few minutes ago that you did not know.
It was very common and it happened numerous times.
where Vietnamese employed by the U.S. military to conduct menial type labor around the garrison units were found to be Viet Cong.
He would fit in with the general Vietnamese during the day, and during the night then he would be fighting a different
There were also numerous instances of where these houseboys or housegirls or kitchen workers or general laborers were used for spying activities.
They were used for destroying American property and general harassment.
In retrospect, 24 years after you served in Vietnam first time, have your thoughts and attitudes changed about the war?
They had definitely changed.
You've got to remember that when I was in the military, and we're talking about this happened 24, 25 years ago, I was completely sold on the military.
That was my job.
That was my profession.
I was not necessarily brainwashed, but I was part of the military establishment at that time.
And as far as I was concerned, we were doing the right thing.
And to a certain extent, I do not say that we were necessarily doing the wrong thing.
In retrospect, yes.
However, I think that we had no part in that war or at very best that it was very ill-advised.
We were trying to
be part and support a government that did not have the people's support, that abused its position, that got religion involved in the war.
that did not have the general vietnamese public's better interest in mind they were being selfish trying to use the government for their own betterment uh that was a local war
that needed to be resolved within their own self, you've got to understand that
got to understand that different parts of the world, you are going to have different societies where they do not necessarily have the same beliefs that we in the United States do.
They also, their economy is different from ours.
Their customs are different than ours.
We just had no

business trying to fight the war for them i think it was very ill-advised thing however i also feel that given the same circumstances the u.s public is more or less bound to support their government's decision if they cannot
support their government's decision, then they also do not have the right to violently, or through violent actions, oppose the decisions of their country.
The people select, elect the politician to represent them at whatever levels of government.
And in a case as controversial as the Vietnam War was, they still owe to those politicians the respect to try to solve whatever the problem be at whatever means available.
What are some of the reasons you feel that we lost the war?
There is several reasons, not any one of them, that by itself contributed to the loss of the war.
First and foremost, I'm sure that anybody will agree, was the lack of support for the war, not only by the general public,
but by the Congress of the United States.
And by Congress of the United States, I'm talking about the fact that they controlled the actions of the military, and they controlled the purse strings.
They controlled the money.
The military, on one side, was being to go out and fight and win a war.
On the other hand, you had the political activists, the anti-Vietnam War demonstrators, and you had your congressmen.
